column11: Review Text

On November 23, 2025, our group of thirteen, travelling with Flamingo Lanka, visited the Twin Ponds – locally called “Kuttam Pokuna” – located within the Abhayagiri Monastery complex in the World Heritage city of Anuradhapura. The two ponds though similar in width at 15.5 metres each, differ in dimensions.  The southern pond measures 40 metres in length and 5.5 metres in depth while the northern pond is 28 metres long and 4.3 metres deep.  Historical records suggest that the ponds were constructed during two different periods between the 6th and the 9th centuries, with the smaller pond being the older.  Over time, both ponds have undergone several renovations. The ponds are remarkable for their precise construction.  Granite slabs, expertly cut and dressed, were used for the bottom, sides, terraces, and steps.  Notably no mortar was used to join the granite blocks, showcasing the advanced engineering and masonry skill of its ancient builders.  The design also features intricate stone carvings and mythical stone figures. The water is supplied to the ponds through underground ducts from a reservoir approximately 3 kilometres away.  This sophisticated system includes a filtration mechanism and a stone chamber to trap sediment.  The two ponds are interconnected by an underground duct.  The water drained from the ponds was historically used to irrigate downstream rice fields. The ponds served as bathing places for the monks residing in the monastery complex at Abhayagiri temple.  Today the Twin Ponds – Kuttam Pokuna – stand as an outstanding example of ancient technical and artistic craftmanship, as well as remarkable examples of hydraulic engineering and architecture skills of ancient Sri Lanka.

These two swimming-pool-like ponds were fascinating to see. I'm told  water enters the larger pond through the mouth of a mythical beast and then flows to the smaller pond through an underground pipe. There was a five- headed guardstone in the shape of a cobra which is nearby the water filter system. The whole area is peaceful and serene.

column8: Well preserved pair of historic bathing ponds
column11: These large twin ponds or pools are well preserved old bathing ponds in Sri Lanka. They were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient Anuradhapura Kingdom. They are important developments in the field of hydrological engineering, architecture and art of the ancient Sinhalese. Interesting to see them. Easy access and not much walking. Wear comfy shoes, hat, sunscreen, take water. Entry fee for the whole complex

The Twin Ponds, or Kuttam Pokuna, are a true hidden gem in Anuradhapura. I was genuinely amazed by the architectural precision and the peaceful atmosphere surrounding this ancient royal bath. Built over 1,200 years ago for Buddhist monks, the ponds were designed with such skill that even today, the drainage system still works! The symmetry, the stonework, and the steps leading down to the water all show the brilliance of early Sri Lankan engineering. What struck me most was the sense of serenity — it’s a quiet, beautiful space where you can imagine the calm daily life of monks centuries ago. The reflections in the water, the birdsong, and the sense of history made it one of the most memorable spots on my trip. Tip: Go early in the morning to enjoy the soft light and peaceful surroundings. Don’t miss the base stones nearby that once held wooden columns — another sign of ancient innovation.

Kuttam Pokuna (twin ponds or pools) are well preserved old bathing tanks or ponds in Sri Lanka. This pair of ponds was built by the Sinhalese in the ancient Anuradhapura Kingdom. They form part of the Abhayagiri vihāra complex and are an example of the works in the field of hydrological engineering, architecture and art of the ancient Sinhalese

Not only are the baths themselves special because of their history and the huge blocks of granite that have been used, but the most special is the filter system that supplied the baths with fresh water every day from one of the reservoirs around this place. The system of that time still works like our current well. The dirt sinks down and an overflow leads the clean water to the baths. Our wells are plastic only. Ingenious thinking.

These are well preserved old bathing tanks or ponds in Anuradhapura. They were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient Anuradhapura Kingdom. They form part of the Anhavagirl vihara complex. Eth Pokuna (elephant) is the largest of the bodies of water on the Abhayagiri vihara complex. I had a photo of me standing by he ponds with a snake around my neck and a monkey on my shoulder!

The Ottoman Bath was reserved for the Sultan’s harem. Artifacts of a bygone era, the time of Ottomanrule, are shown. Women were segregated from men this was their bathhouse Today they have musical concerts

The Twin Ponds (Kuttam Pokuna) are well preserved bathing tanks or ponds in Anuradhapura built by the Sinhalese and form part of the Abhavagri complex. Eth Pokuna (Elephant Pond) is the largest and I have a photo of me with a snake around my neck and monkey on my shoulder

column8: Wish I could swim in it
column11: Just let your imagination run wild. You should let this transport you to 2,000 years ago to get impressed by it.

Twin ponds is merely not an attractive set of ponds but a place where one can observe ancient water purification and desilting system, sending water column through scientifically designed set of stone containers. Steps give access to water at any level and platforms give access along the perimeter of the pond. Structure is all in stone and polished to give neatness while decorative ornaments adore the beauty of the construction. The floral vases (Pun kalasa) at the entrances to the two ponds differ in design. A five hooded Cobra image on the wall is extremely beautiful.

These are two pleasant pols of water. Look out for the various birds that come when you are walking around the site. On one site are a range of stalls selling mainly tourist stuff. However, over the road is a shop that sells large bottles of coke at a good price. Good to cool down with on a hot day.

This is part of the Anuradhapura Ancient City with entrance fee of LKR4,550 per person per entry. Kuttam means twin and Pokuna means pond, so it is literally the twin pond. It was built since Anuradhapura Kingdom as far back to 4th century. It is regarded as one of the significant architecture in terms of hydrological engineering by the Sinhalese. Beautiful and artistic architecture with peaceful surroundings. Fishes can be sighted in the ponds too. It is essential to hire a driver service while visiting Anuradhapura site since the attractions are located pretty far from one another. Nice place to stop over for 15-20 mins visit.

This has been built by great Sri Lankan kings.  It's made of two similar swimming pools. One pool is slightly smaller than the other.  They are made out of granite.  around the pools you could see a granite wall with Ancient Sri Lankan carvings. There's a belief that ancient Sri Lankan stone masons had a technology to soften the Granite.
Very scenic pair of ancient tanks. Part of the sacred city and included in the ticket price for that area
There are twin baths right next to each other. This is the only place you’ll find such a juxtaposition. That’s it.

The pools, made out of granite, were constructed around 500 A.D. They were for the use of the monks. Water entered one of the pools through the mouth of a makara, a mythical beast with the mouth of a crocodile, the body of a fish and the trunk of an elephant. Underground piping connected them. They are different sizes and depths.
Interesting when you see it and read the debrief at the site....nice for clicks as well...a different dimension to Anuradhapura
That pond is nice especially the carved cobra, but the view is ruined by too many shops on one side.

This shows off the water engineering skills of the ancient Sri Lanka. There are two ponds here, used as bathing tank by ancient kings and queens. Later, these ponds given to monks and has attached to the Abayagiri stupa complex. Situated in Anuradapura sacred area, most people tend to visit this place with their families. As of the architectural value of these ponds, its so popular among the travllers.

These baths are huge.  You can really appreciate how they were used, when and why as you approach. It was fascinating to be told about the old drainage and filtering systems to keep the water clean, which goes to show how smart our ancestors were. It was very quiet here and you could happily walk around, take pictures and enjoy the scenery without a rush
This old structure will reveal the engineering g expertise of ancient Sinhalese and the well established monastic tradition which contributed to the spiritual and natural well beingof the people.

Worth the visit on your tour of sacred places and ruins. The twin bath are in very good condition and maintained by the department of archeology. The. Water filtering system is also interesting and certainly very clever for the time. I’d advise to get a historical guide for the day. We found ours by the main Tourist Ticket Office next to the Archeology Museum ( Museum is closed every Tuesday!). Our guide cost us 3000LKR for the day (4 hours). He took us to all the interesting areas of the ruins. We would have never seen all this and got the history of the site without him. He also communicated with our driver so we were driven and picked up in all the right places. One last advice, at the end of the day, keep your tourist ticket. Do not give it back. Not sure what the trick was there but we kept it and were checked subsequently twice on the roads by guards. Without our ticket we would have had an issue I’m sure! And we could visit an extra site with our driver.
The twin baths are nice to visit but only if you have time to spare, there isn't much built around the ponds.

An amazing engineering feat of ancient times. The twin ponds are where monks would take their daily baths. The naga sculpture ( a snake like structure) in the northern pond is the guardian of the water. Many art pieces are feature in these ancient sites each representing a different aspect of the art and history of the time.
That is a amazing historical technologies of the Anuradhapura kingdom for the ponds for their day today activities.
This was really interesting as the twin ponds/baths which were well engineered as our guide explained their purpose and how they worked.
These pools are well engineered but by comparison to the neighbouring relics really not of great interest.

Having seen the smaller royal bath in the ancient city of Polonnaruwa, I was quite impressed by this older twin bath in Anuradhapura. Massive granite slabs, an underground duct with filtering system to bring water to the pool and the decorations around the massive pools was very interesting. It's very grand. Once again having a driver/guide drive you around this massive ancient site on an always hot or hotter day made it more enjoyable. This area was not as shaded as the pond area in Polonnaruwa so be prepared for the searing heat of the sun.
We had a fab guide who was really knowledgeable and was able to give us loads of information, plus point out the most interesting carving etc.

Like other reviews i say many of the key sites at Anuradhapura. For the temples you will need respectful clothing. It was really hot visiting the site so when not in temple wear a hat have sunscreen and lots of water.
I did all the temples in one day, they’re all very beautiful and worth a visit. Enjoy Anuradhapura! Take respectful clothing, water and sun screen.
These were bathing pools used by the King & his followers. A quieter area of the great site. Watch out for the monkeys here, they stole lots of tourists items.
This was definitely one of our highlights of Anuradhapura.  Having seen many temples around Sri Lanka we were a bit exhausted.  This is a beautiful, quiet place to sit and reflect a while.
Very old pools which are feed from underground means. Rebuilt years ago but are beautiful to see. People feed the fish in the pools. Very photographic.

Just away from the mighty temples of Anuradhapura, are the twin baths of the monks of old. Watch out for thieving monkeys here and admire the craftsmanship of these magnificent baths. After a very hot and tiring visit to the oldest temples of Anuradhapura, a fresh shell of coconut juice was most welcome and we sat sipping the delightful drink just adjacent to these baths. It's an area of great peace and beauty and a welcome haven from the busy main tourist drag; well worth a visit at the chance to explore your inner self!
Unusually for this archaeological park these pools are relatively intact and well preserved and make for an interesting stop on your tour.
The twin ponds are a great place for a rest during your tour of the sacred city. Usually, there are not so many people. You can watch the fishes and we even saw two turtles.
Nice to imagine what life would have been like for the king and his court.  Nice detailed carvings, worth a visit.

Twin ponds, but not exactly twins with one much larger than the other. Attractive, but only if you think in the context of trying to imagine the city at its pomp when these would have been the bathing pools fed by hydrological engineering allowing water to be fed through underground ducts and filtered before flowing to the pool.
This bath area has been discovered in the dig-for older and younger monks who lived in the temple. Interesting to see and imagine their way of life
I can't imagine bathing regularly in ponds like these, but that is what happened back in the day, it doesn't happen now. (That I know of.) The water is green-ish.
There are two baths, one older than the other. Because of the growing amount of people living on the terrain, one was not enough in the end.

From my Blog: A quick ride from Abhayagiri was Kuttam Pokuna, two baths which lay on the side of the road and are flanked by yet another shanty market. Though the baths themselves are not the most impressive bodies of water you can view, it was a rare experience to see the spiritual power these baths had over those more devout than I... As I sat next to the pools, a line began to form at the top of the steps leading down to the bath. One by one, people began to descend down to the water and take a small scoop of water which they’d then drop on their head and put a few drops in their mouth’s. Though I’ve never been to India or witnessed the spirituality of pilgrims at the Ganges, I can only assume seeing these people at Kuttam Pokuna was as powerful as witnessing those at the banks of that storied river.

Detailed and Interesting rock carving of the twin baths, even more interesting the engineering involved in supplying the water, back in the 8th century when the work was supposedly completed. With the palace itself practically gone, its hard to imagine how the entire place looked like when everything was standing and functional... Compared to the treasure troves of Dambulla and Pollonaruwa, to us, the royal twin baths are only marginally attractive and of interest...
This is where the King and Queen bathe days gone by.The pond is well maintained. A very good place to take a photo.
The twin baths are worth stopping at. You'll see interesting architecture and, if with a guide, you'll get the history.

These were large bathing tanks that catered to the needs of the monks and staff of the Abhayagiri and were built around the 8th century. Water was filtered several times before flowing in to the ponds through a dragon headed spout. Other noteworthy features are the beautiful carvings around the ponds and the snake shaped guard stones.
This place serves as an epitome of the creativity,art and technology of ancient Sri Lanka. This is a must visit if you want to see the miracles the old kings had performed in the ancient times.
This pond was believe that used by King Dutugemunu and his bunch of Queens. There are two identical ponds, but only King and his main queen used one pond.
One can only imagine how grand and impressive such monuments were in their day. I still believe it is possible to bring it all back to full function.

The Twin Baths are absolutely huge and considering how long ago they were commissioned and built, they represent a truly remarkable feat of engineering. As the name suggests there are two ornate stepped baths side by side with beautiful carved steps and gates. There are two pools, one for the monks to wash and cleanse themselves and one to enter when washed and essentially rinse! There is a working filter system at one end that keeps the water relatively clean but the guide says they are totally drained before the monsoons so as to allow new water to accumulate during the rains. We'll worth a short stop, great for pictures.

The trees were flowering during our visit in July, which made this particularly beautiful to visit and photograph. It wasn’t too busy so could photograph without tourists popping into frame all the time. Interesting construction. Could use more English language details on history and construction and use.

So this place has massive potential but even the local guides aren’t quite sure what was happening here. Suggest coming up with a cool story of kings and Buddha’s of past that resonates with people and going with it. Monkeys all over the joint.
Really nice architectural and artistic design. worth visiting. You could only imagine how the royals enjoyed at the time they used the baths!
This is a bath that the royal families had their baths. The beauty of this is greater when seen from above. I wish I was alive in the era when these baths were used by royalty.
Nothing great, but if you love history and culture then you can relate it to the early days and imagine how their life would be in those days.
Boring  for us. Just two square ponds used years ago now half empty and not cery clean wgen we visited

honestly ... towards the end of a long hot day visiting ancients sights and temples in and around Anuradhapura ... We were in and out of the van within 10 minutes.  This is all we could manage.  However we knew we were seeing a remarkable engineering fete and because of that I can honestly rate it excellent and I am glad I have seen it.
Visited this alongside other nearby sites.  It was a tranquil place with an interesting history, great architecture and engineering skills.

These pools are interesting because of their engineering. It never ceases to amaze me what people come up with to manage their access to water. Especially in parts of the world where it is in abundance some times of the year and more scarce in others. There are tourist stalls around the pools but the vendors are fairly low key.
Went here during our tour and found the site very interesting. The construction of the first pool was impressive but the requirement for a second one seems amazing in this day and age.

These two bathing ponds were filled by guiding water into a pool, the sediment would have sunk alowing the clean water to overflow and into a pipe. The water then came out of a lion-s head spout into the bath. Apparently, the King and others would disrobe in a private area made of silks and other fabrics before entering the bath via the ornate steps. I had wondered why there was a cobra carved into the bath's side; my guide informed me that it is a symbol of prosperity and good luck. Would we visit this site again? Yes.

The twin bath is located a little away from the other main tourist spots of Anuradhapura. But is a beautiful place to go. It's filled up with water during the rainy time which gives a fantastic sight. This pair of pools known as Kuttam Pokuna (Twin Ponds/Pools). The said pair of pools were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient kingdom of Anuradhapura. These are considered one of the significant achievements in the field of hydro logical engineering and outstanding architectural and artistic creations of the ancient Sinhalese. A garden was landscaped which separates the two ponds which long is 18½ ft. The larger pool of the two is 132 ft by 51 ft, while the smaller pool is 91 ft by 51 ft. The depths of the two pools is 14 ft and 18 ft for the smaller pool and the larger pool respectively. Some believe that in a lovely condition evidently the Queen entered from the far end pond and the King nearer the road ornate reliefs at either end some local souvenir and drink stalls around. And the other belief is that these ponds are built inside the Abayagiriya Monastic complex. These polls used by Buddhist monks to take bath. Not for the King and Queen. ( as explained by the British archaeologists) This monastic complex having more than 50 pools. All these are for the Buddhist monks. Twins ponds are only 2 of them. This is nice witness of ancient hydraulic irrigation system from the ancient time this all historical sites used as  monasteries. These both pools were not built in the same time. Small one built earlier and later time built big one. Wonderful work of the Lankan hydronic engineers of Naga tribe. It could understand easily. Because there having 5 headed cobra pillar. That explains it was built by the Naga Tribe.  It must have been an impressive city in ancient times. Lots of interesting ruins are found around here. It is best explored by a bike early in the day. It is a great and amazing place. When you visit this place you will be surely amazed about the ability of the ancient ancestors of Sri Lanka. The carvings and all the construction is breathtaking and unbelievable. This is a beautiful place to take some photos with some different ruins and sculptures. Lots of fish in the water you can feed with. There two swimming pools built adjacent to each other. One is small and having 2 entrance to the water. Other one is bigger and having 3 entrances to water. Water was filtered and cleaned before sending to the pool. The filter system is uncovered and you can see it. The big tank gets water from the small one. There is a square tube between the 2 pools. Exit of the water only is the small one. There is a difference between the stairs. Small one stairs covered the entrance to left and right side. But that mistake was corrected in the big poll.  That explains small one built earlier than the big one. During the past, a lot of Buddhist monk practiced Buddhism reality path from here according to the evidence 5000 monk has lived here. Stone pots with carvings are found and they are decorating the entrance which enhances its beauty. I recommend you to visit it.

We think technology is for modern man, but those who lived in the past were much wiser than we give credit for.  This huge man made tank (dam) supplies water into the bath area through a system of water &  drainage channels.  The baths are made from huge granite stones.  This site has a lot of potential if the Government could afford to re-establish the gardens & surrounding area.  Overall it is well worth visiting.

This is also one of the must sees of Anuradhapuras ancient city. Its location is near many of the other sites, so its worth going by bike. A wonderful historical site. Best to go in the morning or late afternoon, as it gets very hot during the day. Bring water, or buy from some of the vendors,  at slightly inflated prices.

It is a part of UNESCO world heritage site of Anuradhapura. It is a masterpiece of ancient advanced technology built by Sinhales. It was used by monks for bathing. Underground inlets & outlets for water. There are 2 tanks. Larger one is 132'length,51'breadth,18'depth. Smaller is 91'length,51'breadth,14'depth. All walls & floor are made by cut pieces of granite. There are flight of steps with support. Large pots decorate it. Well laid garden also. Few small souvenir shops . Entry ticket for SAARC Nationals is $12.5 or LKR 1937.5 /per person For other tourists is $ 25 or LKR 3875 /per person This is for all Anuradhapura sites.
The twin baths are certainly an impressive piece of craftsmanship build in stone and filled by an ingenious draining system providing water to the whole are during the rainy season.

These ponds were - just like some others - contructed in a specific way and include a few details (cobra, turtle and other ornaments). It included a water filter system and underground connections at a time when such things were unknown in Europe.

These ponds are in really good condition and are separated by a raised walkway. The pools are connected underground. On the 2nd smaller pond at the rear is a carved 5 headed snake as well as a lion ( I believe this was a water spout). The  monks used these pools for their ablutions

Twin ritual baths built in the 8th century. Worth a look because of their scale. There are a few stalls on one side selling fruit, drinks and tourist trinkets. The toilets here should be avoided at all costs!

These two pools were used by the monks - the seniors in one, where it seems they just sat at the edge, while or the "juniors" the other pool offered immersion and bathing. The fact that these pools existed is down to some amazing old technology to bring in water from the nearby sources - some of are also man made. This is only part of a large complex for the monks. It gives food for thought on what it must have been like. You do need a guide to give you the necessary insight.
If this is what the baths looked like, imagine what the whole complex looked like when it was still intact and in use. The construction leading water to the bath is amazing.
Another short stop off whilst visiting Anuradhapura. Nice place to relax and very popular with Srt Lankans

Fantastic architecture and well preserved , though the water needed cleaning and local authorities should do more to keep area clean. Must not forget to see the sculpture of the snakes which many visitors may miss as tucked away in one corner
These are a couple of old bathing pools.  They look pretty dramatic and deep and have some good carvings in places.  There are a line of stalls next to them and they are popular with Sri Lankans.

I liked this place. They were the prettiest baths I saw. They are not really twin since they were built at different times, they have different sizes and architecture. We also do not know for sure what was their purpoise. But I thought it interesting something so old had a filtering system
They told us that if you want to get marry you.just have to sit next to pond and.stair into it in silence
Built by one of our ancient king, Kuttam Pokuna had been for the exclusive use of maha Sangha at that time.Recently restored to the present state
This baths is situated in nice park with many religious bulding. Not such a uncommon place, but not a waist of time.
It's a must to see as part of the tour around this place. Stop and absorb it all. Pretty cool taking pics at the bottom of the steps when there is no water in there... Definitely worth the trip

Yet another hydro-logic engineering marvels of the ancient Sri Lanka. A must visit site within the ruins of the sacred city. However I believe the responsible parties should pay more attention to preserve these structures as I believe they are not maintained properly.
Anuradhapura is so extensive and there are so many sites, but this is one of the best. Fantastic stonework and fascinating water engineering.

This place was an unexpected find! When we got there there was a flock of monkeys crawling out of he jungle into these majestic baths. Would surely pass by this during your tour of the ancient city. There are also a few souvenir stands here.

Unfortunately Anuradhapura was the last site we visited on our tour and by that time you are a little Stupa'd, Budha'd and ruined out. It was interesting to see and note some slight discrepancies in who is believed to have used these - we were told locals or monks, other reviewers here say monarchy. Will we ever know? This site is surrounded by vendors, that spoils the effect a little.

In ancient times Kings used to use this pond to do bathing and stuff. It's a really big pond to have a bath. You can just park your vehicle and see this without walking so much. This is a great and nice creation.
Another spot in the ancient city of Anuradhapura which is a must see.  Great design and architecture, but badly needs some maintence
This greatest architecture is so unbelievable and magical and any one should not miss visiting this unbelievable place.
The twin ponds were used for bathing tanks in ancient Anuradhapura city. One side of the pond still exposes the simple way in which the water was filtered before it entered into the ponds

Though this place is of historical importance but has not been well maintained. No description of the historical importance is available at the site. The water in the tanks is very dirty and should be changed or cleaned regularly to make it a good attraction

Great place to visit. Just to appreciate how they could have constructed these so well, so long ago. Full of vile green water now - but did have fish and a turtle swimming in it (amongst the other rubbish)

This place made a change from visiting all of the stupas in Anuradhapura and was interesting to see. I imagine it was more impressive in its day, with an advanced system for cleaning the water to allow monks to bathe and ablute themselves. Only small, but definitely stop here on a tour around Anuradhapura.
Ancient bathing tanks which belongs to ancient kingdom of Anuradhapura. Kuttam Pokuna means pair of ponds. Must visit place at Anuradhapura.

This is an extraordinary construction for its' time. The different levels where bathers would sit demonstrates a hierarchy. Despite the colour of the water you will find turtle or two swimming & there is no smell. Definitely worth a visit.
It was such a pride to see this greatest architecture. It emphasizes a hard workings of a great civilization.
Considered as one of the best specimen of great bathing pools in Sri Lanka ... situated in Mahamewna Uyana near to Abhayagiri Sthupa..
The twin baths that are not twins.  This site makes one recognise the engineering at the time to work the water systems in this way.  Impressive

This seems like a swimming pool but it s a bit different with a modern one. Its called twin ponds as there two such ponds and now a days its not in use really ,even though its seems one of the great place to visit and see the and see the ancient technology in those sectors.
These have a big history, These ponds were used by royals thousands years ago. Awesome architecture!
A hydrological piece of engineering in the history of the kingdom of. Anuradhpura. Dress code is relaxed, however please consider this area as religious grounds.
Very close to the main Anuradapura religious places. The value of this place should be taken with the time it was built. Maybe 2300 years back. The structure still remains very solid.
Not really spectacular. You can have a look when you are driving by anyways, but I wouldn't go there just for this...
Place is nice but if you are in hurry you can skip it to see more beautiful places.It was good but when I arrived there place was full with little students :D

Not far from roadside and accessible by car. Our guide proved very useful in painting a broad history of the site. One would need a guide or printed information to appreciate the cultural aspects of the site

Twin Baths (Kuttam Pokuna) For centuries this area had been depopulated by the Malaria Mosquito and the surrounding jungle had reestablished itself, covering the many temples and Stupa built by a long Line of Sri Lankan kings each trying to outdo his predecessor by building bigger and better. Fortunately some have been reconstructed by the Sri Lankan archeological society. One of these is the twin baths at Mihintale, consisting two large bathing pools, these days full of green stagnant water with the odd Terrapin in thrown in. However you can see how the water was changed every couple of days with fresh water where the worlds largest school for Buddhist Monks used to bathe.

The twin baths are part of the Anuradhapura complex and is well worth a visit. Although there is only green stagnant water in the baths, they still provide great insight into the building skills of the ancient Sri Lankans. In order to actually get a good look at this structure, one must decend and then ascend a steep set of ancient stone steps. It is however, possible to get a glimpse of the baths from the top of the steps if you cannot navigate these steps.

Our guide said that this pool never was an empty. In the monsoon time the pool is filled by water from rain. And on sunny days will never evaporate entire water from this pool. The water is still there and prepare for using like in an ancient time...

The twin baths are a feat of engineering that are a bit overlooked in the sheer scale of the Anuradhapura....that said they are quiet and majestic, and one of incredible features of Anuradhapura is that the sites are not only still used, but splattered right across a functional city. These have clever ingress from tank water, and egress out to farming land. Very quiet now, but as we were there on a pilgrimage night to the Bodhi tree, just got a hint of what it may have been like 2000 years ago!
All sites in Anuradhapura including this one are well restored and maintained and worth a visit by all.
The twin baths were interesting. Enjoyed walking around each pool and imagining how busy they would have been. Very quiet place.
This is truly an interesting place of history. The stone layout is amazing. What a place for the people during that time to use and enjoy.
I can imagine that it may once have been very pleasant bathing here. The pools are an interesting feat of construction, but only worthy of a short visit.

These twin baths are part of the Anuradhapura ancient ruins. It is absolutely fascinating how these stone monuments were built. There isn't much to the twin baths but it is a picture worthy moment. This tour should be really be done only if you have a driver as otherwise it is very very hot! Remember to dress appropriately; long sleeves and perhaps in white too as the pilgrims do. This is all sacred land for the Buddhists.

This consists of two ponds which was built for the use of the monks who were resided in Abhayagiriya Viharaya in ancient times. You will be amazed with the architectural design with stone at the ancient time of Sri Lanka.

The place is known for an advance rock carvings dated back to Anuradhapura kingdom (the first kingdom of the country). It locates at the heart of the city and accessible via any mode of transportation. However, there is no public transportation, hence it requires arrange own transport. As name says it has two ponds made out of rocks and history says one dedicates for king and other for queens. However, there are many stories behind these two ponds. It's a masterpiece of an advance rock carving of the country. The visitors should pave an attention to the five headed snake and pot of plenty are true art of Sri Lanka. Nevertheless, I can't understand the scenario behind opening of tuck shops around the area. It requires an authority to reassess whether such shops are needed and those shops disturb the true value of the place.
It's a must to see as part of the tour around this place. Stop and absorb it all. Pretty cool taking pics at the bottom of the steps when there is no water in there...
This was interesting to see, but as these pools are no longer used by the monks it looked like 2 empty concrete pools,

These ponds look link swimming pools and supposed to have been used by Monks before morning rituals and prayers in ancient times.Water enters the larger pond through mouth of Makara( a mythical animal) and flows into smaller pond through an underground pipe.The water filter system and five headed Naga ( Cobra) reflect the engineering and artistic skills of the artisans from yesteryears.There are a line of shops on one side of the banks offering a variety of souvenirs at competitive prices.Don't miss to sip fresh coconut water to beat the heat.
Very good to see the ancient and compare with new swimming pools which we are having now . These are natural ponds and have the best water in the good times !!!

in the middle of buddha temple u find this pool, our tour guide was excellent, preferable to visit either early morning or afternoon because the weather is warm and you are barefoot so the ground is extremely hot
Two baths next to each other. There was lot of sellers next to it. This attraction was free of charge. Nothing spesific.
You can't really rate just the twin baths as they are part of a much bigger, complex and sophisticated site. The whole system of hygiene water and movement is incredible.

As I said at my previous comment, anuradhapura is very big. When you visit there you are giving 25 USD. But one day is also not enough to visit this attraction. But during the park, you should definitely visit twin baths (King and For Queen) , You will definitely love to be there.. Cheers Ernur
I have been to Anuradhapuraya two three years ago. At that time it was clean.  But this time it was drained.
We were driving past it when we stopped to take a look.  Nothing that incredible when comparing it to some of the other local sites.
It is a good experience to see how was the life in this time. You can walk around the Swimming Pools and understand how were running.

One of the best specimen of bathing tanks or pools in ancient Sri Lanka is the pair of pools known as Kuttam Pokuna (Twin Ponds/Pools). The said pair of pools were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient kingdom of Anuradhapura. These are considered one of the significant achievements in the field of hydrological engineering and outstanding architectural and artistic creations of the ancient Sinhalese. The faces of the pools were cut granite slabs which includes the bottom and the sides of the pool. A wall was also built around the pool which encloses the compound. Flights of steps are seen on both ends of the pool decorated with punkalas, or pots of abundance and scroll design. Embankments were constructed to enable monks to bathe using pots or other utensils. Water to the pools were transferred through underground ducts and filtered before flowing to the pool and in a similar fashion the water was emptied.

The pools have an interesting way of looking the same size from some angles, but in my opinion they, as well as many of the temples are overrated. Don't eat my head, I have seen so many in so many countries...
The twin ponds were used by monks for bathing, during ancient times in Anuradhapura.Can be easily accessed. But cannot be happy with the maintenance of the place.
Interesting to visit as part of your tour.  The scale is impressive. See my other reviews in anuradhapura
One of the many many attractions to see whilst visiting Anuradhapura.  We had a guide to explain things to us which was definitely beneficial at a cost of LKR2000

The entry fee of AUD35  is daylight robbery to view this site. Not worth the money and should not be supported. Funds go to the government and nothing is spent on maintaining these sites. Clean up these sites instead of regulating on what the public can and cannot wear.
Serene and breath taking. In the evening, the trees reflect in the water. Culturally significant site.
Twin Ponds are remains of ancient Swimming Pools used by King and his Queens. Built with Rock stones and with automatic Water filling and cleaning.
This place is full of greenery and twin ponds share a promiscuous history. Carvings on the walls are magnificent.
If you travel by tuk tuk or bike you can miss the roadblocks and charges that you cop by car. This place has a very promiscuous history.

It is huge and double pool..the architecture still in good condition One of the best specimen of bathing tanks or pools in ancient Sri Lanka is the pair of pools known asKuttam Pokuna (Twin Ponds/Pools). The said pair of pools were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient kingdom of Anuradhapura. Highly  recommended, near to the railways station

The origins of these ponds are not known but it is thought to have been built during the reign of King Aggabodhi I (575-608). The smaller pond (the northern) one has been constructed first and the larger one at a later stage. They are connected through a pipeline at the bottom. The northern pond is 91 feet (28 meters) long and the other 132 feet (40 meters) . Water to these ponds have been supplied through underground pipelines and the water is sent through several filtering chambers before it falls on the northern pond through a mouth of a dragon. The water from both ponds is drained from a small outlet in the smaller northern pond.

Mesmerizing and amazing piece of architectural work using solid rock. Protected by UNESCO. This is twin huge bath tubs like ponds where the king and queen was bathing. A master piece in high calibure of irrigation structures. A site never to be missed.

Kuttam Pakuna (Twin Ponds) Kuttam Pakuna (Twin Ponds) are two bathing tanks built in the middle of a garden in 6th century AD by King Aggabodhi for the monks and students, as part of Abhayagiri Monastery Complex in sacred city of Anuradhapura. It reflects wonderful skills possessed by the Sri Lankans 2000 years ago in architectural engineering and hydrological technology. Both ponds are 51 feet wide and laid down in a row. The larger one is 132 feet long and 17 feet deep while the smaller one is 91 feet long and 14 feet deep. Underground tunnels were built to fill and empty the ponds.
What a surprise... two thousand years old water storage... still entact... and appealing... a must visit for history lovers
As in India we have lots of these types of ponds we were not impressed by the structure. You may stop for a short photo stop but nothing to keep you interested for long.
The twin baths were built BC for the King and Queen. they are side by side and are exquisitely crafted and would amaze any one with an architectural flair.

Interesting that the baths are not identical in size, there is a wonderful snack bar selling nuts and fresh cut apples with salt and chilli which is amazingly restorative after a sweltering day in the heat.

The twin ponds are beautiful & of architectural value, they were made during the ancient time of the kings, by the Sinhala people, for bathing & for water to be used at the Bodhi temple. It is amazing what knowledge the engineers of that era had as this place is considered a hydrological marvel. A must see when in Anuradhapura.
Two pools, water somewhat green, containing a large number of fish. Part of the Anurdhapura sacred city tour, but not worth going to see specially.
Worth stopping if you're in the area, forms part of the experience of the area but not worth going for individually.
Really enjoyed those, as the architecture is beautiful and u can take really nice pictures with all the cows wandering around.

Nice baths, but not something you won't see somewhere else. Anuradhapura it self is nice, but all the sights are so scattered that you never have the idea that you are visiting an ancient city. The local people are also living in between the ancient stupas and other sights. You can't blame them but it is a pity of the total experience. We liked other big sights as Sigiriya and Polonnaruwa more mainly because of this.
These are baths constructed in the eighth century and used by the monks for their ritual ablutions. They are quite well preserved considering their age.

Beautiful and proportionate stone carvings built by ancient Sinhala rulers. Twin Baths illustrates history of the class system. Both the ponds which are different in size need a fair bit of cleaning up as it is quite polluted and smelly.
with huge hungry fish in the ponds. Very picturesque. Go early, it gets really hot and sunny later. I liked the Queen's pond a bit better, honestly.

The bathing spots for the monks. One side for the senior monks, the other for the main class. Interesting irrigation system to provide a foot bath around the two baths when it was functional. A nice stop on your tour of the city. Still pretty complete, compared to other complex sights.
A great monument built by the ancient kings. Amazing feat of engineering. This shows the talent and the capability of our ancient workers.
This is really one of the best constructions made by Ancient Sri Lankans, It will be really good the government put some funds to clean these two ponds a bit.
Best advice: buy some stale popcorn from the kiosks to feed the fish. This makes for a great photo opportunity. Also, beware of pushy salesmen who WILL follow you to your car.
Given the age of these two baths, you have to wonder at the engineering and skills of water management these people possessed. Spot lots of fish and the occasional turtle too!

It is quite amazing that these baths were built such a long time ago and the filtration system is quite ingenious. However the water was putrid, lots of rubbish around, mangy looking dogs and a strong smell of cow manure did not endear this place to me.
They have good architecture in the walls, and a history story, but after all, it's just two ponds for bathing.
Where monks of the Kings  bath, now the water looks polluted , beautiful stone carvings proportionate without any modern equipment .
We visited the twin baths.  Spent around 30 minutes there not much to see but the two pools where the king took a bath
Twin Ponds are part of the city tour of Anuradhapura and of significance in the overall setup of the ancient city
This place has two large ancient ponds; and they are very beautifully crafted, and a must watch if you are in Anuradhapura.

Honestly, nothing much to see or do apart from two rather unexciting ponds. A quick glimpse from the car may be suffice. Sorry, there are tons of other things in this complex of much greater interest.

We visited the baths as part of our independent tour of Anuradhapura. We'd recommend visiting when you haven't purchased an extortionate - $25 entrance ticket for the day - as it isn't required for this site. The baths are architecturally impressive and worthy of some photographs - so long as you can avoid the litter - which is such a shame.

The twin ponds are said to have served as swimming baths for Buddhist monks in the monastery attached to the Abhayagiriya Dagoba. The two pond are actually different in size. The water flows in to one and then to the other through a complex irrigation  system. The northern one  is about 40m in length and the southern about 28m. It is possible to see all the ancient sites in Anuradhapura in one day.

There isn't much more here to see than what you can in the photo. It was quite pretty and peaceful though and worth a 5 minute drop by as part of a longer area tour. We were on a bike ride through the area so this was part of a packed day.
Lovely peaceful place and beautifully constructed baths with water  that comes from a spring below and only monks can bathe in them.j

This pools are beautiful, have a great ancient architectural work ad nice details. It’s amazing what people could achieve 2000 years ago. Now I wouldn’t like to bathe in the pool because it’s full of rubbish (in and next to it) and the water is green. If authorities will take some time to clean this place it would be fantastic.

The fascination with baths is interesting with a view to the fact that none of them was for the monks as that would have been a fun experience which was forbidden per se. This said, the structure is impressive in size and comes along the way from one sacred site to another. You cannot miss it, but it is not a must.
The history and story of this place is so intersting. But the monument and bath are average. The cost for this park is not so cheap. It includes pollunarawura entrance.

local peoples say KUTTAM POKUNA . and other names are ; TWIN PONDS / TWIN BARTH POND. this place located in the sri lanka fist anciant capital city ANURADAPURA. in biteween ABAYAGIRIYA MONASTRY &  MEDITATION BUDDHAS STATUE.this twine pond histry start from king DUTUGEMUNU . 220 feets long  50 feets wide and 20 feets deep. this site say for us oure ancint singhalees hidrolig engieering knowlage and weel irigation tecnolagy. anciant time this 2 ponds use only budist monks
It was beautiful to see this site. It is maintained well and is quaint and hidden as compared to the rest of the sites in Anuradhapura. Its an architecture delight!
It must have been an impressive city in ancient times. Lots of interesting ruins around here. Best explored by bike early in the day.
This belongs to the abayagiri complex and a good showcase of the hydraulic engineering knowledge of the ancient Sinhalese had.
The twin bath is located a little away from the other main tourist spots of Anuradhapura . But is a beautiful place to to. It's filled up with water during the rainy time. A good spot of photo lovers

This is one of a number of sites in the ancient city of Anuaradhapura.  It is worth a stop to admire the engineering and wonder how 15 000 monks bathed in them.  It's a shame that they are not maintained with fresh water and what water is in them is algae filled rain water.  It's worth remembering all of these historical sites only reopened in 2009 after the civil war and this is a site that will be interesting to see what happens as the tourism market grows.
Beautiful place to take some photos with some different ruins and sculptures. Lots of fish in the water you can feed.

Kuttam poking means Twins ponds or Twins Pool. There two swimming pools built adjacent to each other. One is small and having 2 entrance to the water. Other one bigger and having 3 entrances to the water. These both pools was not built in the same time. Small one built earlier and later time built big one. Wonderful work of the Lankan hydronic engineers of Naga tribe. It could understand easily. Because there having 5 headed cobra pillar. That explains it was built by the Naga Tribe. Water was filtered and cleaned before sending to the pool. The filter system is uncovered. You see. It. The big getting water from the small one. There is a square tube between the 2 pools. Exit of the water only having in the small one. There is a difference between the stairs. Small one stairs covered the entrance to left and right side. But that mistake was corrected in the big poll. That explains small one built earlier than the big one. These ponds are built inside the Abayagiriya Monastic complex. These polls used by Buddhist monks to take bath. Not for the King and Queen. ( like explain the British archeologists) This monastic complex having more than 50 pools. All these are for the Buddhist monks. Twins ponds are only 2 of them.

This review is quite late. When visiting the Sacred City of Anuradhapura the Twin Baths will definitely be included in your itinerary. Both ponds were full of garbarge; I wonder if  any maintenance is being carried out by the local government. I spent only a couple of minutes taking photos.

Fascinating example of ancient engineering.  The water to fill these tanks was brought for a lake miles away.  An ancient type of sluice gate stopped the water long enough to drop suspended sediment before it entered the tanks.  Its a shame it is not more carefully tended today.  Both tanks have accumulated trash floating on their surfaces, marring what otherwise is a grand vision.

These "twin" swimming-pool-like ponds are worthy of a quick photo stop. Our guide told us that they were likely used by monks at the monastery attached to Abhayagiri Dagoba.They are not identical, however.
I was surprised at how lovely these baths are. Since they're right inside the entrance to the Sacred City, it's worth a quick stop.
Interesting symmetrical structure of historic value; clean, large and worth a visit if on the way.  Find out how water is captured and fed into the baths!

We visited this as part of a tour of Anuradhapura with a guide. The engineering involved to fill the baths was impressive, as was the filter to remove sediment as the water flowed in. Simple and ingenious. Worth a 10 minute stop as part of a tour of the area.

this is nice witness of ancient  hydraulic irrigation system .then from the ancient time this all historical sites used as a monasteries .then lot of buddhist monk practiced buddhas reality path from here according to the evidence 5000 monk has lived here at that time so bathing purpose of the monk has been built this  2 ponds  according to the kings order believe water pump near by  giant tank thisa vewa using under ground pottery conduit pipe  system.full pots carvings,and decorated entrance is enhancing  its beauty.
Ancient Sinhalese construction meant for Buddhist priests to bathe.Water taken from far away,Other ruins of famous Anuradhapura kingdom are close by.
The twin baths have beautiful stone carvings.  The engineering is impressive - reminded me of the Romans.  They're in great condition.  A lovely, peaceful place.
These twin ponds are among the handsomest wworks of the anuradhupura piriod. Its very cham ponds. Its have stone carving also..

The pair of pools were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient kingdom of Anuradhapura. These are considered as one of the significant achievements in the field of hydrological engineering and outstanding architectural and artistic creations of the ancient Sinhalese

This pair of pools known as Kuttam Pokuna (Twin Ponds/Pools). The said pair of pools were built by the Sinhalese in the ancient kingdom of Anuradhapura. These are considered one of the significant achievements in the field of hydrological engineering and outstanding architectural and artistic creations of the ancient Sinhalese.A garden was landscaped which separates the two ponds which long is 18½ ft. The larger pool of the two is 132 ft by 51 ft, while the smaller pool is 91 ft by 51 ft. The depths of the two pools is 14 ft and 18 ft for the smaller pool and the larger pool respectively.
Two ponds, well conserved, located in the Northern part of the Anuradhapura site. One is 40m length and the smallest 28m.

There are 2 ponds of average size which were used by the monks for bathing.Having seen a lot of ponds in historical areas with much more stone carvings or much bigger, I did not feel any thing very significant. Place is well maintained and it is interesting to note the way the water was channelised to the pond, filtering out the mud. There is no separate ticket for this place. But I suppose the Anuradhapura area ticket covers this as well.
The baths are mostly intact, unlike other ruined buildings on the site. Worth seeing. But not much to do other than walk around them. There are a few stalls selling tourist tat.

Comparisons can be odious but as a layman I would venture to suggest that the Romans were more advanced than the Sinhalese. Nonetheless this is a great engineering achievement given that it was built around AD600. It was tranquil and interesting.  Worth a look.

These beautifully designed twin pools were serene when we visited in the mid afternoon. There were only two other tourists apart from our group. It was interesting to hear how the original inhabitants developed a water cascading system.  This site is in good condition.
These twin tanks hold a lot of fish and tourists can feed. Kids will enjoy. This is a photo spot. This is one of the few spots in Anuradhapura that does not have an entry fee.
Its a nice piece of architecture which depicts how good the Sri Lankans were back in the day at designing.This is just near all other major monuments and sacred places.

They call these the twin pools because they sit side by side, but one is larger and has more staircases down in to it.  All the same it was a pleasant place to visit and not very busy.  Also you can go to the far corner and view the filter system that was used to pour clean water into the pool...
In lovely condition evidently the Queen entered from the far end pond and the King nearer the road ornate reliefs at either end some local souvenir and drink stalls around.

The Kuttam Pokuna or twin baths are one of our favourite features of the many historic sites in Anuradhapura. The two pools were constructed by the Sinhalese for bathing purposes and are an outstanding achievement in terms of hydrological engineering of the time. Not only are they of archaeological and scientific interest but they are also a wonderful artistic feature. They have flights of steps leading down to the water which are decorate with scrolls and other artistic features. One can stand peacefully enjoying the tranquillity of the pools today whilst imagining Monks bathing in ancient times.
It is very good to have water space in a monastery complex, it is a solid stone building, but not a beauty.

Anuradhapura is one of the most historic towns in Sri Lanka and history goes back to 11th Century AD. “Kuttam Pokuna” is one of the historic monuments in this city, but there are so many other monuments surrounding this as well. “Kuttam” means pair (two) & “Pokuna” means pond in native Sinhala language, so you will see two identical ponds opposite each other. As per the history, one pond (pool) is for the king & other one is for the queen, but not sure about accuracy of that data. If you love history and Pyramids, Anuradhapura is one the similar places to visit – but please make sure you do your research first, if not you might not enjoy it.

This is one of the Ancient swimming pools which depict capabilities of ancient engineers in Sri Lanka. It is made out of Granite with intricate carvings which will tells us how good was the technical know how of Sri Lankan craftmen. Kuttam Pokuna means Twin ponds. Build during King Agbo (575-608) period. May have been used by Monks. Great hydraulic marvels that must be visited by any one visitng Sri Lanka.
The beautifully built stone baths were supposedly for monks to bathe in. Stop here for 10 minutes on a tour of the anuradhapura sights. You can buy cold drinks nearby. Boy it gets hot.

Along with many other sites locally, and there are a great many, these are superb examples of ancient Sinhalese architecture and aqua engineering.  This was a very advanced and sophisticated civilization and these two beautiful granite faced pools are yet more evidence of that, as well as being very photogenic.

Despite being green and poorly maintained, these enormous baths were apparently built to act as a laundry for the many hundreds of monks living nearby. Our guide advised us that they were definitely not built for the pleasures of swimming as fun and recreation was denied the monks . Pity, really - they look well worth a cooling dip...

Like most things on the Anuradhapura circuit, by themselves they are fairly boring, but adding the total of all sights makes it worth the trip. Yeah, the baths are old, but they have rubbish in them and basically are a stepped swimming pool with stagnant water.

It is believed that these to beautiful ponds were bulit for the use of the Buddhist monks. Although they are called twin ponds, the two ponds are not identical. A great example for the advanced architectural knowledge of the ancient Sinhalese.

This is one place ancient splendour still remains intact in Anuradhapura. Most places of worship has been restored with out preserving its archeological value intact. One would wonder among such restorations and will be lost at new construction has taken prominence over intended object. This place and several other places which are not places of worship has escaped the wrath of so called beatification in the name of restoration. If you are into history, archeology or just love ancient cities you wold love the place. Some effort in cleaning the water will make the place more appealing to foreign tourists.

Included in the general entrance fee for Anuradhapura city complex this is an interesting short attraction visit. You will only take a few minutes to view this pair of bathing pools and marvel at the  sophistication in engineering achieved over 2000 years ago. A number of market stalls adjacent and one or two beggars in the area. Public toilets (rare occurrence in Anuradhapura) 50 metres away and whilst not luxurious are usable for 20 rupees. Not a must do but worth stopping if passing.
Far away from the city,no buses on that route,tuk tuk are very expensive.............................................
well because it was part of the tour we went here but it was nothing so exciting about this place.. if you have time then visit..
The baths are beautifully built and the history including how water was supplied to them is fascinating. The monks used them to bath in but other people weren't allowed to swim there.

It seems odd that each site within Anaradhupura has it's own review here. As this was my favourite part of Anaradhupura I thought I would allocate my review to the Kuttampokuna (twin baths). The quietness of the baths, amazing intricate nature of their design and proxinity to a very good and inexpensive small place to eat draws me to them. Also, their resident turtle was friendly and an attraction in himself. I thought that given the size of Anaradhapura a driver or in our case cycles are a necessity. I estimate we cycle about 12-15km but saw only two thirds of the area. Sign posts are lacking and it is easy to miss certain sites within the area. There is so much to see in this ancient city that it is another must see place while in this part of Sri Lanka. Anaradhapura is let down by lack of sign posts and seeming lack of reinvestment of the tourist dollar.

They are really beautiful, not exactly the same size, even if called twin pools. Nowadays I wouldn't put a foot in, the water doesn't look clean enough for an European. But you can imagine how it must have been.

What strikes out is these twin ponds are ancient. The multi-headed naag at the end of one of them impressive and really hard to photograph. There is an interesting system of silt chambers to collect all silt from the water before it enters the ponds

The twin baths are yet another testament to the once upon a time grandeur of one of Sri Lanka's native kingdoms. I have to admit that before visiting Anuradhapura, I was not aware that Sri Lanka had such a long and rich history, that it had a civilization that was complex and advanced enough to rival that anywhere else. The whole time I was staring at the twin baths, I kept thinking "How could the people have afforded to build these back then? Where was the source of their wealth?" The twin baths, after all, are very big, especially for just two people. It can thus be looked at as either a symbol of wealth and power and/or waste and frivolous spending. Regardless, the twin baths are definitely worth a look, simply because they are so well preserved, even after a thousand years, unlike many of the other relics in and around Anuradhapura. Just be careful not to fall in! The water is indeed very green!

This was supposedly the place where the king used to take his bath. Nothing much to see here other than two bath places filled with greenish water. It's not even fit to be classified under 'Attractions'. Can be totally skipped!

A relaxing stroll in the park kind of setting.  The trees shield the site from the sun so it's nice and cool to walk through.  When we visited, not a lot of tourists were there, a picnic under the trees by the twin baths should be nice!

Another glimpse of the awesome history of the past of Sri Lanka. Almost everything here is intact to this day. It is reported that an advanced filtration system was in operation to provide fresh water to these pools. The make shift huts that double up as souvenir stalls can be much improved by the authorities as they present a poor picture.

Two beautiful water tanks crafted so many centuries ago, Kuttam Pokuna still invokes a sense of serenity and awe. The ponds are beautiful to admire with intricate stone work surrounding them, but even more impressive is the fact that they had a filtration system designed and installed so long ago. Hands down the best water feature in Anuradhapura. I spent quite a long time sitting and enjoying the calmness at three ponds and was rewarded with several wildlife sightings including turtles, hummingbirds, fish, monkeys and dragonflies. I recommended climbing down the stairs and sitting right near the surface of the water.

I must admit that the highlight of all the sites in India/Southeast Asia are the water features at the palaces/temples and monasteries.  This one is no exception.  The sit contains two large pools with well sculptured stone and various carvings.  Though the site was crowded, it was able to accommodate the numbers and still seem serene.  There was also a lack of litter.

Allthough the twin baths are interesting, it's much more amazing to relase they made these intricate waterworks so many centuries ago. And could you please use some of the massive entree fees(US$ 25)  to Anuradhapura historical site to clean up all the litter. Would show as much respect for these sites as taking of your shoes.

This is an amazing example of the structural and hyrologogical engineering of the ancients in this area.  For a few rupees you can get some food to feed the fish and turtles in the ponds.    Don't know that I'd swim in it though the algae looks a bit ominous.  Nearby we're some busker snake charmers, pythons and cobra.    Our guide suggested r1000 was far too much to pay to handle the snakes.  He suggested half if not a tad less.
Amazing architecture in Anuradhapura and kuttam pokuna is a very famous pool in Anuradhapura built during the ancient days. Another great site to see if you are in Polonnaruwa.

The two pools and their history are quite interesting.  After a day of buddha images and dagobas, we were happy to look at something new.  We also enjoyed spotting fist and turtles - this might be a good spot for kids.  However, there's not much to see, so it's probably a 15 minute stop total - only worthwhile if you are already in the area.
This place was neat and well preserved. It is a long way from the other sites so need a car to get there. It is also free, at the others you need to pay.
Two baths with water. Nothing particularly interesting about them. If you are walking or cycling around I wouldn't make a detour for it.
I would say for me it was just two pools with water. But good for someone who understand and appreciate ancient engineering which is not impressing for me personnely.

Kids were fascinated with these "twin baths " which is a marvel in the field of hydrolic engineering . Isn't it amazing that there were underground conduits which would channel  the water to the pond and were filtered using a  filtration system before flowing into the pools centuries ago ? These twin baths are a short walk from the car park.
Fortunatly our guide was able to add to the experience by pointing out some of the otherwise overlooked features. Very tranquil setting.

On your visit around the sacred sights of Anuradhpura it is well worth having a quick visit. Just to think how craftsman carved these huge slabs of rock to construct these pools is amazing. There is even a filtration system installed.
Two bathing pools aligned lengthwise exemplifying the artistic achievements of hydraulic engineering in ancient Sri Lanka. They date back to between 8-10 AD
Only need a 5-10-minute stop to see the beautiful workmanship of these pools.  There are souvenir stands along side and a "snake charmer" with a cobra when we were there.
Its a beautiful place, the irrigation technology is once again amazing, it was in ruins, but has been restored.
These are two square pools next to each other.  They contain green slimy water.  Not much to see here.

Kuttam pokuna or this twin pond is totally build with granite rock and is as large as a large tennis court. Historically it is said that the former kings who had been governing this country during the 26th and 17th centuries had built these two ponds which are located side by side, for the purpose of bathing mainly reserved for Buddhist monks as those kings had greatly respecting the Buddhist monks who were following the preachings of lord Buddha. The construction of this pond , with out the aid of modern technology or the modern machines is a great marvel of the ancient people who lived those days. Any one visiting Anuradhapura sacred city should not miss to watch the twin ponds.

Sri Lanka is one of the very few countries in the world that has an ancient " Tank Civilization" as against River bank civilization. The ancient  city of Anuradhapura has to be understood from this perspective. The Kings excavated Tons upon Tons of earth / clay to build irrigation tanks to feed the agricultural lands. The excavated clay went to build all the temples, edifices and dwellings that made the mega cities. The building of tanks was so meticulously scientific, in that there was free flowing water supply over thousands of hectares for bathing and even for washing feet before entering a temple with craftily designed very shallow canals which you had to cross before entry to the place of worship. Twin Baths are large Swimming pools with terraces, with constantly regulated water inflows and outflows. Such grandeur, such sophistication !!
A real engineering excellence. Said to be the bathing ponds of the Buddhist Monks. Very beautifully done. The curio vendors near it are too pushy.

Our guide explained that 5000 young monks used the larger pool, which featured places to sit and chat and horse about.  The smaller pool was simply a place for senior monks to wash/bathe. The most amazing feature of the town pools was the remarkable irrigation and filtration system.  The engineers and hydrologists who lived 1500-2000 years ago had an incredible knowledge of hydraulics and underground irrigation.
These are basically as described in their name.  You can admire the building skills that went into creating them, but the visit should only take about 20-30 minutes.
Best evidence of great craftsmanship in that era. Carved out of genuine stone. Avoid midday to avoid heat. No fee.

It's a nice place to visit, i took maybe 5 min to see the whole place. It's a amazing old site, wel kept. The only negative point is that there was a lot of trash in the bath, it was really nasty. The local people need to keep an eye on that, than it would be an amazing thing!

One could imagine the people of old taking a cooling bath here! On one hand, it's amazing that tou can get this close to something this old and sacred, on the other hand it's worrying when more and more tourists will make their way up there!
it was nice to see the twin baths, but it's not a huge site, so it was a good thing it was on our way

It is a wonderful site that Sri Lankans can be proud of. But it was putty to see a few plastic bottles and many plastic bags floating on the water. The garbage pile with food waste a few yards from the pond was another thing I thought should not be there if the site needs to be protected for the future generation. The shops very close to the pond should not be allowed to operate so close.

Let me first preface by saying Anuradhapura, of the "cultural triangle" sites, is the most out of the way, and least worth your while as a result.  I would only recommend it if you were staying in Sri Lanka over 10 days or if you are a big historical/cultural buff.  The ruins at Polonuwara and Sigiriya are more impressive. The baths themselves are worth about 5-10 minutes of your time, hardly worth the amount of time taken just to get there, especially if you are using a bicycle or public transport.  They are, after all, the ruins of two baths (enter drumroll...).  The surrounding area is decidedly not tourist friendly, unless you prefer that look.  There are filthy (and closed at the time of my visit) bathroom facilities, a small shack selling a drink across the road, and lots of cows wandering about.  The area around was muddy (since it had rained recently), and the pools are not closed off.  Good as it preserves a better "look", but bad if you have small children. I would recommend only at the tail end of a visit to Anuradhapura, which itself I would only recommend as a bottom tier attraction within Sri Lanka.  The exorbitant entrance fees alone make you almost obligated to enter.
They are two man made ponds, with a bit of history.  So if you don't appreciate the history, it's two ponds.
Most people visit these baths and other places near Anuradhapura after 10 AM - Stay one night and visit early (start at 7 AM) and see them deserted which is good for pictures.
You have to admit that the water management of previous eras was both far sighted and well engineered. Not a big site but certainly worth seeing.
The two ponds  shows  the techniques of water conservation used by ancient Sri Lankans, you can visit the Ath pokuna which is also  nearby

Not much detail but beautifully constructed ancient pools. Very atmospheric even in heavy rain which is when we were there. Stop to look and walk around the pools. You'll appreciate the workmanship and the beautify of these ancient pools.

If you are visiting the Abhayagiri Vihara monastery complex, it is worth stopping to look at these ponds. Located at the side of a current roadway, the ponds are thought to bathing pools for the monks who resided in the monastery. The southern pond features a water spout in the form of a makara, and a guardstone featuring the Naga symbol (cobra).
